newsitem.title: INDIA: Delhi shares rebound on mutual fund buying.
newsitem.headline: Delhi shares rebound on mutual fund buying.

text.p: Strong buying by domestic financial institutions coupled with short covering by speculators reversed early losses and drove share prices to a higher close on the Delhi Stock Exchange, brokers said.
The bourse's benchmark index closed 3.38 points higher at 683.20.

"The emergence of financial house buying to check the persistent fall in the share prices and purchases by speculators in the wake of rising trends revived the depressed market," said Atul Sondhi of brokers Santur Financial Services.
Traders said the reprieve could prove temporary as the market was still on edge over political uncertainty.
Former prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao's legal woes in two separate criminal cases have kept financial markets on the tenterhooks.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's centre-left coalition depends on the support of Congress to survive in parliament against a challenge from the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).
The market anticipates stains between Congress and Deve Gowda's minority coalition.
Reliance Industries inched up 0.40 rupee to 188 rupees.
ACC gained 25 rupees to close at 1,690, while Apollo tyres quoted 7.25 rupees higher at 119.75 on institutional support, brokers said.
TELCO rose 8.0 rupees to 403 and Hindustan Lever gained 10.25 rupees to 775.50.
However Larsen and Toubro bucked the trend to quote 5.25 rupees lower at 209.
